awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Technologies for the Reproducibility of Biological Computational Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Simulation models of biological and physiological systems have been increasing in number and complexity over the last 20 years, and they are an important means to truly advance understanding of these complex systems.  The impact of these models will be increased if they can be shared easily and accurately between research groups and so that they can both model and be validated with broader sets of data.  The Center for Reproducible Systems for Biomedical Modeling at the University of Washington seeks to develop tools to: 1) build reproducible models; 2) to annotate models using a unified techniques; and 3) reproducibly simulate, analyze, and visualize models online.  The outcomes of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award will provide the research community with tools to make published models more understandable, visualizable, and reusable.  The research team will contribute to various workshops and conferences to highlight the work and train users in the new tools and standards. In addition, the project includes a plan to host afternoon science activities at SoundBio, a maker-space organization that focuses on biology, that would include hands-on and computational exercises for high school and middle school students.

This EAGER award will support efforts of the Center for Reproducible Systems for Biomedical Modeling to: 1) develop a smart annotation editor to assist users in an unobtrusive way with the annotation of models through the addition of metadata; and 2) develop a human-readable standard for describing simulation experiments, such that the precise conditions of the experiment could be recreated through multiple platforms and systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The reproducibility of scientific research is the cornerstone of the scientific method. It allows researchers to build on past work, add confidence to existing research, and help move a field forward. In this work, we developed approaches to help make scientific research, particularly computational work in the biological sciences, more reproducible. We focused on two areas. The first is the ability to describe a computational experiment (that is, a series of calculations) in a way that can be reproducible, irrespective of how the work was actually done in the original study. This enables research to be repeated in the future without reference to the original authors. We developed two specification documents and organized breakout sessions with various stakeholders in the biological modeling community. Since the end of the award, we are organizing a second breakout session in the fall of 2023 to continue this discussion as well as develop some prototypes in collaboration with other groups. In the second project, which was much more developed during the study, we developed an easy-to-use software platform that allows users to add additional information to a biological model so that it can be more easily understood by future researchers. This work has resulted in the submission of a peer-reviewed paper describing the work. In terms of broader impacts, we reached out to a variety of stakeholders both in the biological and biomedical fields to gain feedback on our work. In addition, we continued work on developing extremely affordable textbooks books for college undergraduates, especially in biochemical modeling and control theory.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2023
Modified by: Herbert M Sauro
